content:
Abstract> Abstract # This almost class-less CSS library turns your HTML document into a website that looks like aÂ LATEXÂ document. Write semantic HTML, addÂ <linkÂ rel="stylesheet"href="https://latex.now.sh/style.css">Â to theÂ <head>Â of your project and you are good to go. The source code can be found on GitHub atÂ https://github.com/vincentdoerig/latex-css.
Contents> Contents # Getting Started Class-based Elements Author and Abstract Theorems, Definitions and Proofs Proofs & Theorems Lemmas Definitions Language Support Sidenotes Alternative Typeface HTML Elements Text Formatting Blockquotes Definition Lists Tables Images Miscellaneous Scroll Overflow Syntax Highlighting Dark Mode Getting Started> Getting Started # AddÂ <linkÂ rel="stylesheet"Â href="https://latex.now.sh/style.css">to theÂ <head>Â of your website or install the package usingÂ npm install latex.css.
(optional) Add any classes to elements described in theÂ next section.
(optional) Add dark mode by adding theÂ latex-dark-autoÂ class to theÂ <body>. More infosÂ here.
(optional) If you need support forÂ LATEXÂ math, add the following script to includeÂ MathJax:
<script id="MathJax-script" async src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@3/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js"></script> (optional) If you need syntax highlighting, add the following script to include PrismÂ and the Prism LaTeX stylesheet (or use any other):
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://latex.now.sh/prism/prism.css"> <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/prismjs/prism.min.js"></script> Done.
Class-based Elements> Class-based Elements # Author and Abstract> Author and Abstract # Use the following code to add an author and abstract to your document. It will look likeÂ this.
<p class="author">John Doe <br> December 7, 2020</p> <div class="abstract"> <h2>Abstract</h2> <p>...</p> </div> Theorems, Definitions, Lemmas and Proofs> Theorems, Definitions, Lemmas and Proofs # Theorems, definitions, lemmas and proofs are supported. Just wrap your content in a div and add the corresponding class to the element like in the following example.
<div class="theorem">...</div> <div class="definition">...</div> <div class="lemma">...</div> <div class="proof">...</div> Below are some examples.
Proofs & Theorems> Proofs & Theorems # The real numbersÂ $R$Â are uncountable.
IfÂ $R$Â is countable, then [0, 1] is countable as well. Hence there exists a map C fromÂ $N$Â onto [0, 1] with $C(n) = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} c_i(n) 10^{âˆ’i}$ whereÂ $c_i(n) \in$ {0,1,â€¦,9},Â are the digits in decimal expansion. Now consider a real numberÂ x=âˆ‘i=1âˆcÂ¯i10âˆ’iâˆˆ[0,1]withÂ cÂ¯iâ‰ ci(i). ObviouslyÂ C(n)â‰ xÂ for allÂ nâˆˆN.Â HenceÂ CÂ is not onto. A contradiction.
IfÂ SÂ is both countable and infinite, then there is a bijection betweenÂ SandÂ NÂ itself. 1
For anyÂ sâˆˆS,Â we letÂ f(s)Â denote the value ofÂ kÂ such thatÂ sÂ is theÂ kÂ the smallest element ofÂ S.Â This map is well defined for anyÂ s,Â because there are only finitely many natural numbers between 1 andÂ s.Â It is impossible for two different elements ofÂ SÂ to both be theÂ kÂ the smallest element ofÂ S. HenceÂ fÂ is one-to-one. Also, sinceÂ SÂ is infinite,Â fÂ is onto.
Lemmas> Lemmas # An even number plus an even number results in an even number.
Definitions> Definitions # A definition is a a statement of the meaning of a word or word group or a sign or symbol. 2
Language Support> Language Support # The labels of theorems, definitions, lemmas and proofs can be changed to otherÂ supported languageÂ by including the following snippet, linking to the desired language in addition to the main CSS file.
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://latex.now.sh/lang/es.css" /> ... <html lang="es"> Take a peek at theÂ language support demoÂ to see how the labels of the different languages change.
Sidenotes> Sidenotes # Sidenotes can be used as an alternative to footnotes, where the user does not have to jump to the bottom of the page to read it. On mobile, click the superscript to reveal the noteYay, sidenotes!. If you are on mobile, I will appear inline. If you are using a larger screen, the sidenote will appear to the right of the text..
Sidenotes do need a little bit of setup, they are made up of a label, an invisible checkbox on top of the number and a span with the text inside. The superscript is set automatically and incremented using CSS when the checkbox has a class ofÂ sidenote-number.
<label for="sn-1" class="sidenote-toggle sidenote-number"></label> <input type="checkbox" id="sn-1" class="sidenote-toggle" /> <span class="sidenote"><!-- sidenote content --></span> If you do not need superscripted numbers, you can opt out of theÂ sidenote-numberclass and the sidenote will not have a number assigned. On a smaller screen, you will need to add a symbol inside theÂ labelÂ for the user to click on.Â This is a sidenote without a number.
The snippet for a sidenote without a number is very similar:
<label for="sn-anything" class="sidenote-toggle">âŠ•</label> <input type="checkbox" id="sn-anything" class="sidenote-toggle" /> <span class="sidenote"><!-- sidenote content --></span> Add a class ofÂ leftÂ to the span with theÂ sidenoteÂ class to make the note appear on the left side of the page on instead of right.
The symbol you could use to indicate a sidenote is up to you. What about this notebook.Â A notebook indicating a note. Aha.Â (if on a large screen, resize to mobile to see the emoji)
Dark Mode> Dark Mode # There is built-in support for dark mode. By default, the document is in light mode. To enable dark mode, add theÂ latex-darkÂ class to theÂ <body>Â element. This will force the document to be in dark mode.
If you want enable dark mode based on theÂ prefers-color-schemeÂ CSS media query, then use theÂ latex-dark-autoÂ class instead.
You can also add a dark mode toggle to your site by adding a button and a tiny bit of JavaScript:
<button id="dark-mode-toggle">Toggle dark mode</button> document .querySelector("#dark-mode-toggle") .addEventListener('click', () => { document.body.classList.toggle("latex-dark"); }); Like this:Â Toggle dark mode
Alternative Typeface> Alternative Typeface # LATEX.css uses Latin Modern by default. If you don’t like this typeface (hard to read, too thin, etc.), you can switch to theÂ LibertinusÂ font family by adding a class ofÂ libertinusÂ to theÂ <body>Â tag. Click the button below to switch between Latin Modern and Libertinus.
Current typeface:Â Latin Modern
HTML Elements> HTML Elements # For a preview of all HTML elements with LaTeX.css, check out theÂ HTML5 elements test page.
Text Formatting> Text Formatting # This sentence isÂ bold. If you like semantics, you might go withÂ strongÂ orÂ emphasizedÂ text. If not,Â italicÂ is still around.Â SmallÂ text is for fine print. Your copy can also beÂ subscriptedÂ andÂ superscripted,Â inserted,Â deleted, orÂ highlighted. You would use aÂ hyperlinkÂ to go to a new page. Keyboard input elements likeÂ CmdÂ +Â ShiftÂ are used to display textual user input.
Blockquotes> Blockquotes # Give me six hours to chop down a tree and I will spend the first four sharpening the axe.Â -- Abraham Lincoln Definition Lists> Definition Lists # Definition Title One
First definition description
Binomial theorem
$$(x+y)^n = \sum_{k=0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} x^{nâˆ’k} y^k = \sum_{k=0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} x^k y^{nâˆ’k}$$
Tables> Tables # A sample table with a descriptive caption.
Header 1 Header 2 Header 3 Description 1 Description 2 Description 3 Description 1 Description 2 Description 3 Footer 1 Footer 2 Footer 3 Example table taken fromÂ this paperÂ on how to produce quality tables with LaTeX.
Item Animal Description Price ($) Gnat per gram 13.65 Gnu stuffed 92.50 Emu stuffed 33.33 Armadillo frozen 8.99 Color names and values.
Name HEX HSL RGB Teal #008080 hsl(180, 100%, 25%) rgb(0, 128, 128) Lightcoral #f08080 hsl(0, 79%, 72%) rgb(240, 128, 128) Goldenrod #daa520 hsl(43, 74%, 49%) rgb(218, 165, 32) Cornflowerblue #6495ed hsl(219, 79%, 66%) rgb(100, 149, 237) Images> Images # Mountain landscape byÂ John Towner.
Miscellaneous> Miscellaneous # Scroll Overflow> Scroll Overflow # It is best to break up long equations into smaller parts, but when this isn’t possible, consider wrapping the overflowing element with a class ofÂ scroll-wrapperÂ to allow scrolling on the x-axis. Large tables should also be wrapped with this class.
Below is an example of a long equation with overflow scroll.
$$(1+x)^n = 1 + nx + \frac{n(nâˆ’1)}{2!} x^2 + \frac{n(nâˆ’1)(nâˆ’2)}{3!} x^3 + \frac{n(nâˆ’1)(nâˆ’2)(nâˆ’3)}{4!} x^4 + \frac{n(nâˆ’1)(nâˆ’2)(nâˆ’3)(nâˆ’4)}{5!} x^5 + â€¦ $$
Syntax Highlighting> Syntax Highlighting # If you need syntax highlighting for code, LaTeX.css provides aÂ PrismJSÂ theme that immitates theÂ mintedÂ package for LaTeX. Add the following stylesheet and script:
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://latex.now.sh/prism/prism.css"> <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/prismjs/prism.min.js"></script> And use it like this:
<pre> <code class="language-html"> <!-- your HTML code snippet --> </code> </pre> Change which languages Prism highlights by customising the scriptÂ here.
FromÂ https://www.math.brown.edu/~res/MFS/handout8.pdf.Â â†©
â€œDefinition.â€ Merriam-Webster.com Dictionary, Merriam-Webster,Â https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/definition. Accessed 18 May. 2020.Â â†©
